{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{Infobox television | show_name = Miranda | image = Miranda (TV series) title.png | genre = [[Sitcom]]
[[Cringe comedy]]{{cite web |url=http://www.complex.com/pop-culture/british-tv-shows-you-should-be-watching/miranda |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-05-11 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170523005912/http://www.complex.com/pop-culture/british-tv-shows-you-should-be-watching/miranda |archivedate=23 May 2017 |df=dmy-all }}
[[Farce]]https://www.ft.com/content/6f7183c4-b844-11e7-9bfb-4a9c83ffa852https://www.telegraph.co.uk/tv/2016/10/16/sarah-hadland-miranda-is-coming-back/https://itunes.apple.com/gb/tv-season/miranda-series-1/id401621876https://www.comedy.co.uk/tv/miranda/shop/ | creator = [[Miranda Hart]] | writer = Miranda Hart | director = [[Juliet May]]
Mandie Fletcher | starring = {{Plainlist | * [[Miranda Hart]] * [[Tom Ellis (actor)|Tom Ellis]] * [[Patricia Hodge]] * [[Sarah Hadland]] * [[Sally Phillips]] * [[James Holmes (actor)|James Holmes]] * [[Bo Poraj]] * [[Adrian Scarborough]] }} | theme_music_composer = Alex Eckford | country = United Kingdom | language = English | num_episodes = 20 | list_episodes = List of Miranda episodes | executive_producer = Jo Sargent | producer = Nerys Evans (2009)
Emma Strain (2010–13)
Sarah Fraser (2014–2015) | location = [[BBC Television Centre]] (2009–13)
[[The London Studios]] (2014/15 specials) | camera = [[Multiple-camera setup]]
[[Videotape|Video]] (2009–15)
[[High definition video|HD video]] (on location 2014–15) | runtime = 30 minutes
35 minutes (2014/15 specials) | network = [[BBC Two]] {{small|(2009–10)}}
[[BBC One]] {{small|(2012–15)}} | picture_format = [[16:9]] ([[1080i]] [[High-definition television|HDTV]]) | first_aired = {{start date|df=y|2009|11|9}} | last_aired = {{end date|df=y|2015|01|01}}{{cite web|url=http://entertainment.stv.tv/showbiz/283907-miranda-hart-wont-do-another-miranda-series/|title=Miranda Hart won't do another Miranda series|date=25 July 2014|accessdate=17 August 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140819085558/http://entertainment.stv.tv/showbiz/283907-miranda-hart-wont-do-another-miranda-series/|archivedate=19 August 2014|df=dmy-all}} | website = http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00w7dv9 | num_series = 3 (+ 2 specials) }} '''''Miranda''''' was a British television [[sitcom]] written by and starring comedian [[Miranda Hart]]. It originally aired on [[BBC Two]] from 9 November 2009 and later on [[BBC One]]. Developed from Hart's semi-autobiographical [[BBC Radio 2]] comedy ''Miranda Hart's Joke Shop'' (2008), the situation comedy revolves around socially inept Miranda, who frequently finds herself in awkward situations. The show features actors [[Sarah Hadland]], [[Tom Ellis (actor)|Tom Ellis]], [[Patricia Hodge]], [[Sally Phillips]], [[James Holmes (actor)|James Holmes]] and [[Bo Poraj]]. It was filmed in front of live audiences at the [[BBC Television Centre]] and [[The London Studios]]. Receiving positive comments from critics, ''Miranda'' won a [[Royal Television Society]] award and gained several [[BAFTA TV Award]] nominations.{{cite news|url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/tv_and_radio/article6794548.ece|title=The best television for autumn 2009|last=Kinnes|first=Sally|work=[[Sunday Times]]|publisher=[[News International]]|date=16 August 2009|accessdate=8 December 2009}}{{cite web|url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/tv_and_radio/article6898506.ece|title=Miranda Hart stands head and shoulders above the rest|last=Maxwell|first=Dominic|work=[[The Times]]|publisher=[[News International]]|date=2 November 2009|accessdate=9 December 2009}}{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/tvandradioblog/2009/nov/24/miranda-funny|title=Miranda: you are awful, but I like you|last=Frost|first=Vicky|work=[[The Guardian]]|publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]]|date=24 November 2009|accessdate=9 December 2009|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130922201136/http://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/tvandradioblog/2009/nov/24/miranda-funny|archivedate=22 September 2013|df=dmy-all}} The series has since been regularly repeated on British television and is available in the United States through [[Hulu]].{{cite web|url=http://www.hulu.com/miranda|title=Hulu: Watch Miranda online|publisher=[[Hulu]]|accessdate=27 June 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130630032639/http://www.hulu.com/miranda|archivedate=30 June 2013|df=dmy-all}} == Premise == {{main|List of Miranda episodes}} The episodes revolve around the difficulties Miranda ([[Miranda Hart]]) gets herself into. She is {{convert|6|ft|1|in|cm|abbr=on}} tall and, sometimes mistaken for a man, is addressed as 'Sir'. She has never fit in with her old boarding school friends, Tilly ([[Sally Phillips]]) and Fanny ([[Katy Wix]]), and finds social situations awkward, especially around men. She is a constant disappointment to her mother, Penny ([[Patricia Hodge]]), who is desperate for her to get a proper job and a husband. Although Miranda owns and lives above her own [[wikt:joke shop|joke shop]] and [[boutique]], she lacks any real capacity for business, so it is managed by her childhood friend Stevie Sutton ([[Sarah Hadland]]). The restaurant next door is initially run by Clive Evans ([[James Holmes (actor)|James Holmes]]), until series three, when the restaurant's chef, Gary Preston ([[Tom Ellis (actor)|Tom Ellis]]), purchases it from him. After many failed attempts at dating, Miranda and Gary, a friend from university whom Miranda fancies, decide to be just friends. Nevertheless, when Gary gets a girlfriend called Rose ([[Naomi Bentley]]), it prompts Miranda to start a new relationship with Michael Jackford ([[Bo Poraj]]), a local reporter whose work soon takes him to Africa. Upon his return he proposes to Miranda, as does Gary when he realises his love for her. Miranda accepts Gary's proposal rather than Michael's and Miranda and Gary get married in the final episode. == Cast== {| class="wikitable" |- ! rowspan="2"|Actor ! rowspan="2"|Character ! colspan="4"|Seasons |- ! style="width:50pt;"|1 ! style="width:50pt;"|2 ! style="width:50pt;"|3 ! style="width:50pt;"|Specials |- ! colspan="6" style="background:lightgrey;"| [[Ensemble cast|Main cast]] |- | [[Miranda Hart]] | Miranda | colspan="4" {{cMain}} |- | [[Tom Ellis (actor)|Tom Ellis]] | Gary Preston | colspan="4" {{cMain|Main}} |- | [[Sarah Hadland]] | Stevie Sutton | colspan="4" {{cMain|Main}} |- | [[Patricia Hodge]] | Penny | colspan="4" {{cMain|Main}} |- | [[Sally Phillips]] | Tilly | colspan="4" {{cMain|Main}} |- | [[James Holmes (actor)|James Holmes]] | Clive Evans | colspan="2" {{cMain|Main}} | colspan="1" {{cNone}} | {{cGuest}} |- ! colspan="6" style="background:lightgrey;"| [[Recurring character|Recurring cast]] |- | [[Katy Wix]] | Fanny | {{cRecurring}} | colspan="3" {{cNone}} |- | [[Margaret Cabourn-Smith]] | Alison | colspan="4" {{cGuest|Guest}} |- | [[John Finnemore (writer)|John Finnemore]] | Chris | colspan="4" {{cGuest|Guest}} |- | [[Luke Pasqualino]] | Jason | {{cGuest|Guest}} | {{cNone}} | {{cGuest|Guest}} | {{cNone}} |- | [[Adrian Scarborough]] | Dreamboat Charlie | colspan="3" {{cGuest|Guest}} | {{cRecurring|Recurring}} |- | [[Dominic Coleman]] | Customer | {{cGuest|Guest}} | {{cNone}} | colspan="2" {{cGuest|Guest}} |- | [[Stacy Liu]] | Tamara | {{cNone}} | {{cGuest|Guest}} | colspan="2" {{cNone}} |- | [[Bo Poraj]] | Michael Jackford | colspan="2" {{cNone}} | {{cRecurring|Recurring}} | {{cGuest|Guest}} |- | [[Naomi Bentley]] | Rose | colspan="2" {{cNone}} | {{cRecurring|Recurring}} | {{cNone}} |} * [[Miranda Hart]] as Miranda – An ungainly, socially awkward, 35-year-old woman who frequently finds herself in bizarre situations.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00w7dv9|title=Miranda at BBC.co.uk|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150123064515/http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00w7dv9|archivedate=23 January 2015|df=dmy-all}} She is something of a misfit relative to her upper-middle-class, privately educated background, opting to invest an inheritance from her uncle in a joke/gift shop rather than pursuing what her mother perceives as a more "respectable" career, and balking at the supposedly "suitable" men that her mother and friends try to set her up with. Miranda struggles with everyday adult life, often indulging in odd, childlike behaviour (including adding faces and clothes to pieces of fruit and vegetables, dubbing them "Fruit Friends" and "Vegeta-Pals") and getting thrown out of numerous establishments. Although this often irritates her friends and family, they tolerate her because, at heart, she is intelligent and good-natured, despite not always showing it. In the final episode, after she breaks up with Gary, some of her awkward and childish behaviour disappears; this causes considerable concern for her friends and mother, who organise a therapy session. However, she finally accepts that her only serious problem – her lack of confidence – is now gone and although she does not need Gary, she does indeed love him. After an initial panic over an unexpected wedding, she marries Gary at his restaurant. * [[Tom Ellis (actor)|Tom Ellis]] as Gary Preston – A handsome, friendly chef; an old university friend of Miranda's. Although there has always been an undercurrent of attraction between them, neither has pursued it until he begins working at the restaurant next to Miranda's shop. Despite often being confused by Miranda's behaviour, Gary generally finds her kind, open nature endearing, especially as she is willing to help him out when needed. Gary is more confident and worldly than Miranda, but he shares her insecurity in romantic situations, and occasionally becomes embroiled in odd situations with her {{mdash}} for example, the pretence that they have sons called "Cliff" and "Richard" when challenged by a customer in the shop. He is one of the few people who accepts Miranda as she is. Miranda and Gary date briefly in series two, though this breaks down when it is revealed Gary was married (for a green card) to a waitress that Miranda had befriended at the restaurant. Gary also dates Rose briefly in series three, before breaking up with her due to her being unable to accept Miranda. After becoming engaged, Miranda becomes concerned that he has never said he loves her. When she confronts him, Gary tells Miranda that her distinctive lack of confidence in herself means that they can never truly be together. In the final episode, when Miranda accepts herself, she rushes to what she believes is Gary's wedding, where he is actually best man for his former boss Clive. Gary reveals he has already decided that he loves Miranda and offers to elope; she decides that she does not need to run away and marries Gary at Clive's reception. * [[Sarah Hadland]] as Stevie Sutton – Miranda's childhood friend, and the assistant manager of the joke shop (although in reality she does most of the work due to Miranda's lack of business sense). She is generally more level-headed and ambitious than Miranda, but is not averse to becoming involved in her strange behaviour, or indeed indulging in some of her own, including frequently performing [[Heather Small]]'s "[[Proud (Heather Small song)|Proud]]" while holding a cardboard cut-out of the singer whenever she is pleased with herself.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=idNNIUUg5NE|title=Miranda – Stevie sings "Proud" on YouTube|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170215114105/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=idNNIUUg5NE|archivedate=15 February 2017|df=dmy-all}} Because of this, Miranda and Stevie often get into petty arguments and competitions, such as when a customer leaves his wallet and both Miranda and Stevie attempt to impress him. Miranda frequently mocks Stevie for her small stature, and frequently pushes her over when she irritates Miranda. Despite often claiming to have "the allure" and mocking Miranda's attempts with men, Stevie also shares Miranda's lack of success, sometimes coming across as desperate when she chats someone up. She occasionally uses an unkempt and unpleasant traffic warden (played by [[Joe Wilkinson]]) as a date when trying to compete with Miranda. In the final episode, the traffic warden appears again and Stevie kisses him to avoid getting a [[parking ticket]]. * [[Patricia Hodge]] as Penny – Miranda's middle-class mother, a "lady who lunches", who likes to impress her friends and fellow [[Women's Institutes|W.I.]] members. Her main mission in life is to find Miranda a man and a better job. She despairs at Miranda's decision to run a joke/gift shop, and her tendency to reject suitable (or at least available) men, on numerous occasions trying to set up Miranda with her cousin. Although often embarrassed by her daughter, Penny displays many of Miranda's erratic traits and often teams up with Miranda for their benefit, such as when they are in the psychiatrist's office. Despite being prepared to humiliate Miranda for her own gain (to the point of holding up a placard offering to pay someone to marry Miranda), Penny's actions are borne out of genuine love and concern, and on the rare occasions where Miranda is doing well she shows her love by cheering "Go Miranda". Penny's catchphrase, "Such fun!" is normally used to describe an activity or event where she believes Miranda may find a husband. Another catchphrase of Penny's, especially in the first series, is 'What I call', which she says before numerous everyday things before Miranda points out that that is simply the word for it, and not just what Penny calls it (for example, 'I'm meeting a friend for a spot of, what I call, tea.') Penny tends to ignore Miranda's obvious disinterest or discomfort. In the final episode, Penny turns up at Miranda's flat two days after her break-up with Gary, insensitively suggesting they simply find another groom. Miranda finally loses her temper and tells Penny to get out; this causes Penny to go on a drinking binge at her local tennis club. She soon turns up at Miranda's flat and tearfully confesses that her relationship with Miranda's father has been dead for some time. Thanks to her daughter's new confidence, Penny regains her dignity and joyfully embraces Miranda when she marries Gary several days later. * [[Sally Phillips]] as Tilly – An old school friend of Miranda's and the daughter of Penny's never-seen friend Belinda, who fits right in with their private school background, often showing more in common with Penny than Miranda does. Tilly is a socialite and normally quite self-centred, though on occasion, she does come through for her friends and shows that she is kind and generous. She will often address Miranda by her school nickname, "Queen Kong" (due to Miranda's stature and clumsiness), despite Miranda's displeasure, but her criticisms and attempts to help Miranda are generally well intentioned. Tilly's catchphrase is "bear with", usually said as she breaks off conversations to read text messages. While seeming more confident and together than Miranda, she has her own problems romantically, particularly when her fiancé, Rupert (played by [[Adam James (actor)|Adam James]]), makes a pass at Miranda behind her back. In the penultimate episode, she becomes engaged to her army doctor boyfriend, "Dreamboat" Charlie (played by [[Adrian Scarborough]]). The final episode sees Miranda give Tilly tickets to [[Wick, Caithness|Wick]] so she can be free of her mother and elope with Charlie. * [[James Holmes (actor)|James Holmes]] as Clive Evans (2009–2010, 2015) – The [[camp (style)|camp]], vicious-tongued owner of the restaurant where Gary works. He is usually more of a hindrance than help whenever he attempts to help Miranda and Gary get together, accidentally revealing, for example, that Gary has a secret wife from [[Hong Kong]] named Tamara (played by [[Stacy Liu]]). Despite his jibes at Miranda, he does show traits of wanting to help her, such as when he pushes her to tell Gary his true feelings. He is absent from the third series having sold the restaurant to Gary off-screen. Clive returns in the final episode and marries the regular customer from previous episodes (played by [[Dominic Coleman]]). * [[Bo Poraj]] as Michael Jackford (2012–2014) – Miranda's new boyfriend who works as a television reporter and loves Miranda for the real her. Michael made his final appearance in the penultimate episode, when Miranda peacefully turned down his marriage proposal in order to accept Gary's. In the final episode, Penny mentions that the character has flown to Africa, where he had previously returned from on a business venture. * [[Naomi Bentley]] as Rose (2013) – Gary's new girlfriend. When Rose can't accept his past affections for Miranda, Gary breaks up with her. She is last seen entering Gary's restaurant for its re-opening, but when Miranda confesses her true feelings for Gary during an argument, Rose immediately walks out. * [[Katy Wix]] as Fanny (2009) – Another socialite friend of Miranda's from boarding school. She appears during the first series{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm2360449/?ref_=ttfc_fc_cl_t16|title=Katy Wix|work=IMDb|accessdate=8 April 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150802075340/http://www.imdb.com/name/nm2360449/?ref_=ttfc_fc_cl_t16|archivedate=2 August 2015|df=dmy-all}} alongside Tilly, but is not mentioned or seen as of the second series. * [[John Finnemore (writer)|John Finnemore]] and [[Margaret Cabourn-Smith]] as Chris and Alison (2009–2010, 2013–2014) – Sort-of friends of Gary and Miranda. As university students, Chris and Alison agreed to marry each other if they were still single at a certain age, but Chris whisked Alison away to Paris and proposed. During the second series, Alison becomes pregnant and they decide that Gary and Miranda should be godparents, but Miranda freaks out when they reveal she will also act as Alison's birthing partner. In the third series, Miranda, Gary and Rose babysit for them. They make their final appearance in the penultimate episode; their once joyous marriage now strained. * [[Dominic Coleman]] (2009, 2013, 2015) as 'Customer' – A [[homosexual|gay]] man who comes into the store on three occasions,{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0171015/|title=Dominic Coleman|work=IMDb|accessdate=8 April 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160414071035/http://www.imdb.com/name/nm0171015/|archivedate=14 April 2016|df=dmy-all}} usually with the intention of buying something for his niece, but is distracted by the probing questions of Stevie and Miranda and gets roped into their antics (For example, suggesting Miranda should lie about being gay and then being roped into attending her coming out party.) He features in the final episode as the partner of Clive,{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b04wtcsd|title=BBC One – Miranda, Specials, The Final Curtain|work=BBC|accessdate=8 April 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160426011643/http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b04wtcsd|archivedate=26 April 2016|df=dmy-all}} whose wedding Miranda gatecrashes. Although never mentioned on screen, he is referred to on the BBC's website as 'Jim'. == Production == === Conception === Abigail Wilson, who worked for comedians [[Dawn French]] and [[Jennifer Saunders]], suggested Hart pitch a show to the BBC after seeing her perform in 2003. Following a read-through of her script with Saunders and BBC executives, a television pilot, based on her semi-autobiographical writing, was filmed in early 2008,{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/comedy/2009/11/get-ready-for-miranda.shtml|title=BBC Comedy Blog: Get ready for ''Miranda''|last=Hart|first=Miranda|authorlink=Miranda Hart|date=9 November 2009|publisher=BBC|accessdate=21 December 2009|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091228151534/http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/comedy/2009/11/get-ready-for-miranda.shtml|archivedate=28 December 2009|df=dmy-all}} and the series was then developed into a sitcom for radio; ''Miranda Hart's Joke Shop'' aired on [[BBC Radio 2]] in August and September 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00d3hzr|title=''Miranda Hart's Joke Shop''|publisher=[[BBC Online]]|accessdate=9 December 2009|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090624120548/http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00d3hzr|archivedate=24 June 2009|df=dmy-all}} A television series was commissioned in August 2008 and began filming in June 2009.{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2008/08_august/22/comedy.shtml|title=New BBC Two comedy: ''In My Country'' starring Omid Djalili, ''Miranda Hart's Joke Shop'' and ''Rab C Nesbitt'' returns|work=BBC Press Office|publisher=BBC|date=22 August 2008|accessdate=10 December 2009|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090106023056/http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2008/08_august/22/comedy.shtml|archivedate=6 January 2009|df=dmy-all}}{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2009/06_june/18/miranda.shtml|title=Miranda starts filming with an all-star cast for her new sitcom on BBC Two|work=BBC Press Office|publisher=BBC|date=18 June 2009|accessdate=3 November 2009|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090622192932/http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2009/06_june/18/miranda.shtml|archivedate=22 June 2009|df=dmy-all}} Outdoor shots for series one were filmed in Hounslow, West London.{{cite web |first=Miranda |last=Hart |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/comedy/2009/11/get-ready-for-miranda.shtml |title=Comedy Blog: Get ready for Miranda |publisher=BBC |date=9 November 2009 |accessdate=4 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101102221505/http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/comedy/2009/11/get-ready-for-miranda.shtml |archivedate=2 November 2010 |df=dmy-all }} In an interview with the BBC's Writersroom, Hart said of the semi-autobiographical basis for the series:
Well I developed this stand-up persona, and that's where it all started from. I realised I was getting laughs being a version of me, and that's what ended up in the sitcom. You do ultimately start from yourself but I'm pleased to say I did have to exaggerate for comedic effect. It wasn't entirely autobiographical. I'm not quite that mad.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/writersroom/insight/miranda_hart1.shtml|title=Miranda Hart|date=December 2009|work=BBC Writersroom|publisher=BBC|accessdate=10 December 2009|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091213204628/http://www.bbc.co.uk/writersroom/insight/miranda_hart1.shtml|archivedate=13 December 2009|df=dmy-all}}
=== Series 1 (2009) === Each episode begins with a welcome to audience and a 'Previously in my life ...' segment, and Hart says a joke shop is the "right place" as the setting after being asked to consider an office to "normalise" the character. Her love of 1970s comedy programmes, such as ''[[Some Mothers Do 'Ave 'Em]]'', is the influence for ''Miranda''. The episodes end with a 'You have been watching ...' credits section where each cast member waves goodbye, as seen concluding [[Jimmy Perry]] and [[David Croft (TV producer)|David Croft]] sitcoms such as ''[[Dad's Army]]'' and ''[[Hi-de-Hi!]]''.{{cite news|url=http://www.chesterchronicle.co.uk/entertainment-chester/chester-cinema-film-tv/2009/11/09/miranda-hart-harks-back-to-tv-golden-age-59067-25124626/|title=Miranda Hart harks back to TV golden age|work=Chester Chronicle|publisher=[[Trinity Mirror]]|first=Andy|last=Welch|date=9 November 2009|accessdate=4 December 2009|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120227075127/http://www.chesterchronicle.co.uk/entertainment-chester/chester-cinema-film-tv/2009/11/09/miranda-hart-harks-back-to-tv-golden-age-59067-25124626/|archivedate=27 February 2012|df=dmy-all}} Quoted in ''[[The Times]]'', Hart says "I'm saying this is what I'm doing and I'm not scared to do it. Some of my comedy peers do slightly fear being a mainstream figure, as if it's slightly uncool. Well, I thought I'm going to embrace it." Throughout each episode, Hart breaks the [[fourth wall]] and addresses the audience directly, a technique described as a "simple creative decision [that] makes this infectious comedy sing";{{cite web|url=http://www.comedy.co.uk/guide/tv/miranda_hart_sitcom/press/|title=Miranda – Reviews and Articles – British Comedy Guide|publisher=The British Comedy Guide|accessdate=31 December 2009|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101114065806/http://www.comedy.co.uk/guide/tv/miranda_hart_sitcom/press|archivedate=14 November 2010|df=dmy-all}} another critic stated "this is hard to pull off, but it works well". === Series 2 (2010) === Following the conclusion of the first series, the BBC commissioned a second series for BBC Two in 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/tv/news/a191479/bbc-hands-second-series-to-miranda.html|title=BBC hands second series to ''Miranda''|last=French|first=Dan|date=15 December 2009|work=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=[[Hachette Filipacchi Médias|Hachette Filipacchi UK]]|accessdate=15 December 2009|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091223180139/http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/tv/news/a191479/bbc-hands-second-series-to-miranda.html|archivedate=23 December 2009|df=dmy-all}} Of this, Hart said "I am not only relieved but totally overwhelmed by the response and thrilled that people have enjoyed the series. I am very grateful for all the support and to the BBC for giving me the chance to do another series next year."{{cite web|url=http://www.lastbroadcast.co.uk/comedy/previews/v/10182-miranda-to-return-for-series-2.html|title=Miranda to return for Series 2|publisher=Last Broadcast|accessdate=23 November 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110215220227/http://www.lastbroadcast.co.uk/comedy/previews/v/10182-miranda-to-return-for-series-2.html|archivedate=15 February 2011|df=dmy-all}} Filming started during the first weeks of summer, and the new series began broadcast in November 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2009/12_december/16/miranda.shtml|title=''Miranda'' is recommissioned for BBC Two|date=16 December 2009|work=BBC Press Office|publisher=BBC|accessdate=21 December 2009|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100725102000/http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2009/12_december/16/miranda.shtml|archivedate=25 July 2010|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://www.radiotimes.com/ListingsServlet?event=10&channelId=105&programmeId=142158654&jspLocation=/jsp/prog_details_fullpage.jsp|title=Miranda – The New Me|work=[[Radio Times]]|publisher=[[BBC Magazines]]|accessdate=3 November 2010}} The second series comprises six episodes and saw the return of Miranda's mother and friends, Stevie, Gary and Tilly.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2010/07_july/14/funandlaughter.shtml|title=BBC Two Autumn and Winter 2010/2011|work=BBC Press Office|publisher=BBC|accessdate=2 November 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100918215309/http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2010/07_july/14/funandlaughter.shtml|archivedate=18 September 2010|df=dmy-all}} For the BBC broadcast, following the end of each episode viewers could press the [[BBC Red Button|red button]], or go online, to watch Hart interview a guest who had inspired her during the writing of the show.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/bbcinternet/2010/11/whats_on_bbc_red_button_6th_-.html|title=What's On BBC Red Button 6th – 19 November|last=Dawson|first=Lisa|date=5 November 2010|work=BBC Internet Blog|publisher=BBC|accessdate=23 November 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101122063417/http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/bbcinternet/2010/11/whats_on_bbc_red_button_6th_-.html|archivedate=22 November 2010|df=dmy-all}} Hart's friend [[Clare Balding]] was the first guest and they discussed how Balding influenced the character of Tilly.{{cite news|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/celebs/columnists/todays-tv/2010/11/15/miranda-bbc2-8-30pm-115875-22717841/|title=Miranda – BBC2, 8.30pm|last=Simon|first=Jane|date=15 November 2010|work=[[Daily Mirror]]|publisher=[[Trinity Mirror]]|accessdate=23 November 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101120094036/http://www.mirror.co.uk/celebs/columnists/todays-tv/2010/11/15/miranda-bbc2-8-30pm-115875-22717841/|archivedate=20 November 2010|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/comedy/2010/11/precision-engineered-comedy-bbc-two.shtml|title=Precision Engineered Comedy on BBC Two|last=Thair|first=David|date=12 November 2010|work=BBC Comedy|publisher=BBC|accessdate=23 November 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101122133514/http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/comedy/2010/11/precision-engineered-comedy-bbc-two.shtml|archivedate=22 November 2010|df=dmy-all}} [[Frank Skinner]] was interviewed for the second episode.{{cite web|url=http://www.chortle.co.uk/video/2010/11/22/12204/miranda_hart_interviews_frank_skinner|title=Miranda Hart interviews Frank Skinner|publisher=Chortle|date=22 November 2010|accessdate=24 November 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120402161449/http://www.chortle.co.uk/video/2010/11/22/12204/miranda_hart_interviews_frank_skinner|archivedate=2 April 2012|df=dmy-all}} Following the end of episode five, which is a [[two-hander]] between Miranda and Penny, the red-button feature saw Hart interview her real-life mother.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/proginfo/tv/2010/wk46/feature_red_button.shtml|title=Network TV BBC Week 46 – BBC Red Button feature|work=BBC Press Office|publisher=BBC|accessdate=13 December 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130113033611/http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/proginfo/tv/2010/wk46/feature_red_button.shtml|archivedate=13 January 2013|df=dmy-all}} In late 2010, Hart announced that she would be filming a special edition of ''Miranda'' for [[Red Nose Day 2011|Comic Relief]].{{cite web|url=http://mirandahart.com/?p=111 |title=Comic Relief 2011 |publisher=MirandaHart.com |accessdate=14 December 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101107073415/http://mirandahart.com/?p=111 |archivedate=7 November 2010 |df= }} The sketch saw Miranda team up with dancers from ''[[Pineapple Dance Studios (TV series)|Pineapple Dance Studios]]''.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/8390705/Comic-Relief-2011-viewers-guide.html#|title=Comic Relief 2011: viewers' guide|date=18 March 2011|work=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]|publisher=Telegraph Media Group|accessdate=18 March 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110319212741/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/8390705/Comic-Relief-2011-viewers-guide.html|archivedate=19 March 2011|df=dmy-all}} === Series 3 (2012–2013) === ''Miranda'' was recommissioned for a third series by BBC Comedy commissioner Cheryl Taylor in January 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/tv/news/a297773/bbc-hands-miranda-a-third-run.html|title=BBC hands 'Miranda' a third run|first=Ryan|last=Love|work=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=[[Hachette Filipacchi UK]]|date=13 January 2011|accessdate=13 January 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110115192923/http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/tv/news/a297773/bbc-hands-miranda-a-third-run.html|archivedate=15 January 2011|df=dmy-all}} Hart revealed that the third series might not be ready until 2012, but she may write a Christmas special.{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/tv/news/a299722/miranda-new-series-could-air-in-2012.html|title=Miranda: 'New series could air in 2012'|work=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=[[Hachette Filipacchi UK]]|first=Ryan|last=Love|date=24 January 2011|accessdate=26 January 2011}} The following month it was announced that the third series of ''Miranda'' would be shown on [[BBC One]].{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/feb/10/upstairs-downstairs-miranda-bbc1|title=Upstairs Downstairs gets second series as Miranda moves to BBC1|last=Deans|first=Jason|date=10 February 2011|work=[[The Guardian]]|publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]]|accessdate=10 February 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140111141903/http://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/feb/10/upstairs-downstairs-miranda-bbc1|archivedate=11 January 2014|df=dmy-all}} In April 2011, Hart announced on ''[[The Graham Norton Show]]'' that she had set herself to start writing the third series the following month.{{cite episode|title=Episode 3|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b010vd3m|series=The Graham Norton Show|serieslink=The Graham Norton Show|credits=Norton, Graham, Hart, Miranda, Adele, Whitehall, Jack|network=[[BBC]]|station=[[BBC One]]|airdate=29 April 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111012154008/http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b010vd3m|archivedate=12 October 2011|df=dmy-all}} However, Hart revealed in November she had still not started writing the series.{{cite episode|title=04/11/2011|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b016vx2w|series=The One Show|serieslink=The One Show|credits=Evans Chris, Jones, Alex, Hart, Miranda|network=[[BBC]]|station=[[BBC One]]|airdate=4 November 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111106052539/http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b016vx2w|archivedate=6 November 2011|df=dmy-all}} That same month it was announced Hart would not be doing a new Christmas special, though the 2010 Christmas episode would be repeated on BBC One.{{cite web|url=http://mirandahart.com/?p=461|title=Christmas TV appearances|publisher=Mirandahart.com|accessdate=1 December 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111112153355/http://mirandahart.com/?p=461|archivedate=12 November 2011|df=dmy-all}} On 17 December 2011, Andrew Mickel of Digital Spy reported Hart's involvement with BBC One drama ''[[Call the Midwife]]'' had delayed the third series of ''Miranda'' until Autumn 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/tv/news/a356460/no-new-miranda-until-late-2012.html|title=No new 'Miranda' until late 2012|last=Mickel|first=Andrew|date=17 December 2011|work=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=[[Hearst Magazines UK]]|accessdate=17 December 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120107193934/http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/tv/news/a356460/no-new-miranda-until-late-2012.html|archivedate=7 January 2012|df=dmy-all}} Filming on the third series ended in early October 2012.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/women/9595580/Patricia-Hodge-all-the-best-roles-go-to-Judi-Dench.html|title=Patricia Hodge: all the best roles go to Judi Dench|date=9 October 2012|work=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]|publisher=[[Telegraph Media Group]]|accessdate=12 November 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121012005703/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/women/9595580/Patricia-Hodge-all-the-best-roles-go-to-Judi-Dench.html|archivedate=12 October 2012|df=dmy-all}} A month later, a BBC News reporter revealed that [[Gary Barlow]] would appear in an episode of the third series as himself. They stated that he would "get friendly in an unexpected way" with Hart.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-20165790|title=Gary Barlow to star in Miranda sitcom|date=1 November 2012|work=[[BBC News]]|publisher=BBC|accessdate=1 November 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121101182847/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-20165790|archivedate=1 November 2012|df=dmy-all}} The third series began broadcasting from 26 December 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/tv/s104/strictly-come-dancing/news/a442942/eastenders-who-strictly-bbc-one-confirms-christmas-day-lineup.html|title='EastEnders', 'Who', 'Strictly': BBC One confirms Christmas Day lineup|last=Jeffery|first=Morgan|date=4 December 2012|work=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=[[Hearst Magazines UK]]|accessdate=4 December 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121205020230/http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/tv/s104/strictly-come-dancing/news/a442942/eastenders-who-strictly-bbc-one-confirms-christmas-day-lineup.html|archivedate=5 December 2012|df=dmy-all}} The outdoor scenes for the second episode of the third series were filmed in Church Street, [[Kingston upon Thames]].{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/Thekingstonecho|title=Miranda in Kingston|work=Kingston Echo Twitter Feed|publisher=Kingston Echo|accessdate=1 January 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140326125817/https://twitter.com/Thekingstonecho|archivedate=26 March 2014|df=dmy-all}} === Specials (2014–2015) === Due to the cliffhanger at the end of the third series, it was suspected that ''Miranda'' would return for a fourth series. However, in July 2014, Hart announced that there are no plans for a fourth series but 'a couple of specials' would be made. Hart later announced that the two Christmas specials would be the end to the sitcom. Hart said the end was "going to be really emotional," but added that she didn't want her sitcom character "to keep falling over and making a fool of herself".{{cite web|url=http://www.comedy.co.uk/news/story/000001638/miranda_hart_confirms_sitcom_end/|title=Miranda Hart confirms an end to her hit sitcom|date=23 October 2014|accessdate=23 October 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141024171214/http://www.comedy.co.uk/news/story/000001638/miranda_hart_confirms_sitcom_end/|archivedate=24 October 2014|df=dmy-all}} The first special, titled "I Do, But To Who?" aired on 25 December 2014{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b04wtvrs|title=BBC One – Miranda, Specials, I Do, But to Who?|work=BBC|accessdate=8 April 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160421204836/http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b04wtvrs|archivedate=21 April 2016|df=dmy-all}} and the final episode titled "The Final Curtain" aired on 1 January 2015.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-30655881 |title=Miranda fans get happy ending in finale of hit sitcom |publisher=BBC |work=BBC News |date=2 January 2015 |accessdate=4 January 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150104050343/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-30655881 |archivedate=4 January 2015 |df=dmy-all }} === Future === At the end of the final episode, Miranda said to the audience/viewers: "I don't know when and if I'll see you again..." In June 2015, Miranda Hart revealed that she hadn't ruled out a possible return for ''Miranda''.{{cite web|url=http://www.express.co.uk/entertainment/tv-radio/582430/Miranda-Hart-return-Tom-Ellis-Gary-sitcom|title=Miranda Hart is not ruling out sitcom return with children – TV & Radio – Showbiz & TV – Daily Express|author=Neela Debnath|work=Express.co.uk|accessdate=8 April 2016}} Sarah Hadland has suggested that the sitcom is set to return. Speaking in an interview with The Telegraph, the actress – who plays Miranda's friend Stevie in the show – confirmed that the comedy will be back "in some format". However, she wouldn't be drawn on specifics, just saying: "I can say there will be something".{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/tv/2016/10/16/sarah-hadland-miranda-is-coming-back/|title=Sarah Hadland: 'Miranda is coming back'|author=Jasper Rees|access-date=4 November 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161104210326/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/tv/2016/10/16/sarah-hadland-miranda-is-coming-back/|archivedate=4 November 2016|df=dmy-all}} In late May 2017, Tom Ellis suggested the possibility of future episodes in an interview on [[BBC Radio 2]], saying that "we may be revisiting Miranda in the next couple of years".{{Cite news|url=https://www.thesun.co.uk/tvandshowbiz/3703228/hit-comedy-miranda-is-set-to-make-shock-return-two-years-after-the-finale-saw-character-marry-gary/|title=Miranda is to make a shock return two years after the hit comedy's 'finale' saw character marry Gary|date=2017-06-01|work=The Sun|access-date=2017-06-01|language=en-GB|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170603065425/https://www.thesun.co.uk/tvandshowbiz/3703228/hit-comedy-miranda-is-set-to-make-shock-return-two-years-after-the-finale-saw-character-marry-gary/|archivedate=3 June 2017|df=dmy-all}} The main cast of ''Miranda'' (aside from Ellis and Holmes), reunited for the 2017 [[Royal Variety Performance]], for which Hart was the host. They appeared several times throughout the evening in character. ==American remake== In August 2018, it was reported that ''[[The Big Bang Theory]]'' star [[Jim Parsons]] was developing a US remake for [[Warner Bros. Television]]. Hart would be involved in developing the remake as a producer, but it was not revealed if she would star as well. https://www.spoilertv.com/2018/08/miranda-jim-parsons-developing-us.html == Reception == The first series was picked as one of the top 10 forthcoming TV shows for Autumn 2009 by ''[[The Sunday Times]]''. Ahead of the first episode airing, Dominic Maxwell in an article for ''[[The Times]]'' described it as an "old-school" sitcom and said that "It's good fun, if you buy into it. And if you do, it's because of Hart." Also describing it as "old-fashioned", Vicky Frost for ''[[The Guardian]]'' said of the [[slapstick]] physical comedy that "It's not clever – but it is funny. And that, I think is at the heart of Miranda's appeal." Mark Wright for ''[[The Stage]]'' said that Hodge gives a "brilliant, brilliant performance" and that "what sets ''Miranda'' out as something special is Hart herself, and the rest just gels around her."{{cite web|url=http://blogs.thestage.co.uk/tvtoday/2009/11/why-we-love-miranda/|title=Why We Love ''Miranda''|last=Wright|first=Mark|work=[[The Stage]]|publisher=The Stage Newspaper Limited|date=24 November 2009|accessdate=9 December 2009|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091126050107/http://blogs.thestage.co.uk/tvtoday/2009/11/why-we-love-miranda/|archivedate=26 November 2009|df=dmy-all}} The first series opened with 2.63 million viewers (10% audience share), rising to 3.14 million viewers (12% share) for the fourth episode.{{cite web|url=http://www.barb.co.uk/whats-new/weekly-top-30?|title=Weekly Top 30 Programmes – BBC2 w/e 15 Nov 2009|publisher=[[Broadcasters' Audience Research Board]]|accessdate=30 January 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wSLX6Azh?url=http://www.barb.co.uk/report/weeklyTopProgrammesOverview|archivedate=13 February 2011|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://www.barb.co.uk/whats-new/weekly-top-30?|title=Weekly Top 30 Programmes – BBC2 w/e 6 Dec 2009|publisher=[[Broadcasters' Audience Research Board]]|accessdate=30 January 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wSLX6Azh?url=http://www.barb.co.uk/report/weeklyTopProgrammesOverview|archivedate=13 February 2011|df=dmy-all}} The second series opened with 3.19 million viewers, rising to 4.01 million viewers for the third episode.{{cite web|url=http://www.barb.co.uk/whats-new/weekly-top-30|title=Weekly Top 30 Programmes – BBC2 w/e 21 Nov 2010|publisher=[[Broadcasters' Audience Research Board]]|accessdate=17 December 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wSLX6Azh?url=http://www.barb.co.uk/report/weeklyTopProgrammesOverview|archivedate=13 February 2011|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://www.barb.co.uk/whats-new/weekly-top-30|title=Weekly Top 30 Programmes – BBC2 w/e 5 Dec 2010|publisher=[[Broadcasters' Audience Research Board]]|accessdate=17 December 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wSLX6Azh?url=http://www.barb.co.uk/report/weeklyTopProgrammesOverview|archivedate=13 February 2011|df=dmy-all}} Rachel Tarley from the ''[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]]'' said ''Miranda'' is an acquired taste and that an episode can be a mixed bag.{{cite news|url=http://www.metro.co.uk/tv/851041-miranda-was-such-fun|title=Miranda was such fun|last=Tarley|first=Rachel|date=20 December 2010|work=[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]]|publisher=[[Associated Newspapers]]|accessdate=22 December 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101224100339/http://www.metro.co.uk/tv/851041-miranda-was-such-fun|archivedate=24 December 2010|df=dmy-all}} However, Tarley enjoyed the festive episode of series 2, saying "Hart got away with a lot of the more irritating qualities of her work, with help from the fantastic Patricia Hodge and Sally Phillips. Tonight was also the first we saw of Miranda's father, played by Tom Conti, who filled most of the episode's falling-over quota, so that Miranda finally remained pretty vertical throughout the episode." She added that Hart is "a great observer of everyday dilemmas" and the best thing of all is she left the door open for a third series. Dominic Cavendish of ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' called ''Miranda'' "the sitcom of the year",{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/8209865/Miranda-Im-the-friend-you-can-laugh-at.html|title=Miranda: 'I'm the friend you can laugh at'|last=Cavendish|first=Dominic|date=21 December 2010|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|publisher=[[Telegraph Media Group]]|accessdate=22 December 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101228032950/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/8209865/Miranda-Im-the-friend-you-can-laugh-at.html|archivedate=28 December 2010|df=dmy-all}} while Chris Harvey of the same newspaper said "The truth is, pretty much every time Miranda turns and looks at the camera, I burst out laughing. And even when her slapstick is so obvious it wouldn't confuse a small child [..] I still laugh. Even when I'm trying not to. Even when I really, really don't want to."{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/8215227/Miranda-love-her-or-hate-her.html|title=Miranda: love her or hate her?|last=Gee|first=Catherine|author2=Harvey, Chris|date=21 December 2010|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|publisher=[[Telegraph Media Group]]|accessdate=22 December 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101224062607/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/8215227/Miranda-love-her-or-hate-her.html|archivedate=24 December 2010|df=dmy-all}} Meanwhile, Catherine Gee said the show was a flop and listed six reasons why, which included unoriginal jokes, Hart's asides to the camera and the show retaining "the worst aspects of the sitcoms of yesteryear." The opening episode of the third series became one of the most watched shows in the UK over the Christmas period, attracting a total audience of over 11.5 million viewers.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/9769498/Why-Miranda-is-now-bigger-than-EastEnders.html|title=Why Miranda is now bigger than EastEnders|last=Deacon|first=Michael|date=28 December 2012|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|publisher=[[Telegraph Media Group]]|accessdate=30 December 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121229222212/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/9769498/Why-Miranda-is-now-bigger-than-EastEnders.html|archivedate=29 December 2012|df=dmy-all}} For The Telegraph, Michael Deacon compares the programme to a childish Christmas panto, finally adding, "Perhaps I’m just getting old. I’m sure I’d have loved this show when I was six." {{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/9764774/Miranda-BBC-One-review.html|title=Miranda, BBC One, Review|date=27 December 2012|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|publisher=[[Telegraph Media Group]]|accessdate=14 August 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140104124337/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/9764774/Miranda-BBC-One-review.html|archivedate=4 January 2014|df=dmy-all}} Keith Watson, writing for Metro, says the series three finale is a "great end to an up-to-scratch season, Miranda never fails to cheer up an evening, reminding many of us that we aren’t alone in the everyday awkward situations that we might find ourselves in – to some extent, anyway."{{cite news|url=http://television.thedigitalfix.com/Content/1258/miranda-306--brief-encounter.html|title=Miranda: 3.06 – A Brief Encounter|date=30 January 2013|work=The Digital Fix|accessdate=14 August 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131204043619/http://television.thedigitalfix.com/Content/1258/miranda-306--brief-encounter.html|archivedate=4 December 2013|df=dmy-all}} [[George Entwistle]] stated, "Miranda's been a tremendous hit with audiences on BBC Two and I'm very glad she's let us persuade her to move to BBC One, where we believe we can build an even bigger following for her multi-award-winning show. BBC Two has done an exceptional job of supporting and nurturing Miranda over a number of years and I'm certain she'll be equally well looked after at BBC One."{{cite news|url=http://metro.co.uk/2011/02/10/miranda-moves-to-bbc1-after-two-series-on-bbc2-637931/|title=Miranda leaves BBC2 for third series on BBC1|date=10 February 2011|work=[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]]|publisher=[[Associated Newspapers]]|accessdate=10 April 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140223003015/http://metro.co.uk/2011/02/10/miranda-moves-to-bbc1-after-two-series-on-bbc2-637931/|archivedate=23 February 2014|df=dmy-all}} == Awards and nominations == In March 2010, Hart won the comedy performance prize at the 2009 [[Royal Television Society]] Awards for her role; the series was also nominated for the scripted comedy and comedy writing (for Hart, Cary and Hurst) awards.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/8543624.stm|title=''Miranda'' show leads TV nominations|date=1 March 2010|work=[[BBC News Online]]|publisher=BBC|accessdate=1 March 2010}}{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/8543887.stm|title=BBC triumphs at Royal Television Society awards|date=17 March 2010|work=[[BBC News Online]]|publisher=BBC|accessdate=13 May 2010}} The series also gained two nominations at the 2010 [[British Academy Television Awards]]: scripted comedy and female comedy performance for Hart.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/tvandradioblog/2010/may/10/bafta-awards-nominations-2010|title=Bafta TV awards 2010: what's your pick of the bunch?|last=Frost|first=Vicky|date=10 May 2010|work=[[The Guardian]]|publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]]|accessdate=13 May 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160306164456/http://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/tvandradioblog/2010/may/10/bafta-awards-nominations-2010|archivedate=6 March 2016|df=dmy-all}} Both Hart and Hodge received Best Actress nominations at the 2010 [[Festival de Télévision de Monte-Carlo|Monte Carlo Television Festival]].{{cite web|url=http://www.tvfestival.com/content/Presentation-Nominees/presentation_nomineesUK.php?menu=smenu2&trk=nom&typeN=2&ER=TC |title=Nominees – Actresses |publisher=Monte-Carlo Television Festival |accessdate=1 July 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717115420/http://www.tvfestival.com/content/Presentation-Nominees/presentation_nomineesUK.php?menu=smenu2&trk=nom&typeN=2&ER=TC |archivedate=17 July 2011 |df= }} In November 2010, ''Miranda'' was nominated for Best Comedy Programme at the [[Broadcast (magazine)|Broadcast Awards]].{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/tv/news/a290639/in-full-broadcast-awards-2011-nominations.html?rss|title=In Full: Broadcast Awards 2011 nominations|last=WightmanSperling|first=Catriona|date=30 November 2010|work=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=[[Hachette Filipacchi UK]]|accessdate=1 February 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121023021049/http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/tv/news/a290639/in-full-broadcast-awards-2011-nominations.html?rss|archivedate=23 October 2012|df=dmy-all}} In January 2011, the show won Best New British TV Comedy at the [[British Comedy Awards]], while Hart won Best TV Comedy Actress and the People's Choice Award For The King Or Queen Of Comedy 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/tv/news/a299572/live-british-comedy-awards-winners.html|title=Live: British Comedy Awards – Winners|last=Bell|first=Amy|date=22 January 2011|work=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=[[Hachette Filipacchi UK]]|accessdate=22 January 2011}} ''Miranda'' was also nominated for Best Sitcom.{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/tv/news/a298153/british-comedy-awards-the-nominations.html|title=British Comedy Awards the nominations|last=Sperling|first=Daniel|date=15 January 2011|work=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=[[Hachette Filipacchi UK]]|accessdate=16 January 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110119014856/http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/tv/news/a298153/british-comedy-awards-the-nominations.html|archivedate=19 January 2011|df=dmy-all}} Hart won Best Comedy Performance and ''Miranda'' was named Best Scripted Comedy at the Royal Television Society Awards in March 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/tv/news/a309195/in-full-rts-awards-for-2010-the-winners.html|title=In Full: RTS Awards for 2010 – The Winners|last=Tobin|first=Christian|date=16 March 2011|work=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=[[Hachette Filipacchi UK]]|accessdate=16 March 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110319040739/http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/tv/news/a309195/in-full-rts-awards-for-2010-the-winners.html|archivedate=19 March 2011|df=dmy-all}} ''Miranda'' earned the award for Best Comedy Show at the 37th Broadcasting Press Guild Awards.{{cite web|url=http://www.broadcastingpressguild.org/2011/03/25/winners-37th-bpg-television-and-radio-awards/|title=Winners – 37th BPG Television and Radio Awards|last=Douglas|first=Torin|date=25 March 2011|publisher=Broadcasting Press Guild|accessdate=27 March 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120311195049/http://www.broadcastingpressguild.org/2011/03/25/winners-37th-bpg-television-and-radio-awards/|archivedate=11 March 2012|df=dmy-all}} Juliet May received a nomination for Best Director at the 2011 [[British Academy Television Craft Awards]].{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/tv/news/a318464/in-full-bafta-tv-craft-awards-2011-winners.html|title=In Full: BAFTA TV Craft Awards 2011 – Winners|last=Wightman|first=Catriona|date=9 May 2011|work=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=[[Hachette Filipacchi UK]]|accessdate=9 May 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110511054121/http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/tv/news/a318464/in-full-bafta-tv-craft-awards-2011-winners.html|archivedate=11 May 2011|df=dmy-all}} Hart and the show received nominations from the [[British Academy Television Awards 2011|British Academy Television Awards]] for Female Performance in a Comedy Role and the YouTube Audience Award '''Miriam Chaszczewacki''' or '''Miriam Chaszczewacka''' (1924–1942) was a 15-year-old Jewish girl and Holocaust victim who in 1939 began writing a personal diary about her life in the [[Radomsko]] [[ghetto]] which ended a few days before her assassination in 1942. == Discovery and publication of the diary == Miriam's teacher Stefania Heilbrunn returned to [[Radomsko]], [[Poland]] after [[World War II]] had ended. While she was visiting the city cemetery, she met a Polish woman who gave her a sealed envelope saying "My son has asked me to give this to you. I don't know anything about it" and left. In the envelope Heilbrunn found a notebook with handwriting she recognized as belonging to her former student, Miriam Chaszczewacki. Heilbrunn brought the notebook to [[Israel]] and published its content.{{cite book|title=Children of Dust and Heaven : A Diary from Nazi Occupation through the Holocaust|last=Heilbrunn|first=Stefania|date=March 18, 2013|isbn=1481865617|page=344}} Originally the diary was written in [[Polish language|Polish]]. Parts of the diary were published in Hebrew, Yiddish, Polish, English and German. The original notebook was donated to [[Yad Vashem]]. == Life == Miriam's mother Sarah Lavit Zelber, born to a [[Hasidic Judaism|Hassidic]] family was a kindergarten teacher and a public figure. Miriam's father Davidתמונתו ופרק לזכרו בספר יזכור ליהדות רדומסקו page 460 was born in [[Ukraine]]. He opened a Jewish school in Radomsko where he taught Hebrew. This school was later active in the ghetto. Miriam's brother Nahum was born in 1929.Children of Dust and Heaven, page 98 Miriam was a 15-year-old [[Gymnasium (school)|gymnasium]] student and a member of a Zionist youth movement when the war began. She is described as a gentle, sensitive, intelligent and talented girl who studied Hebrew in her father's school.נערה בגיטו, page 4. In another testimony, she is described as a shy, romantic and dreamy teenager.{{cite book|title=Children of Dust and Heaven : A Diary from Nazi Occupation through the Holocaust|last=Heilbrunn|first=Stefania|date=March 18, 2013|isbn=1481865617|page=86}} Miriam's father and brother were murdered in the ghetto by the Germans. The father, David, was killed for refusing to board a deportation train.{{cite book|title=Children of Dust and Heaven : A Diary from Nazi Occupation through the Holocaust|last=Heilbrunn|first=Stefania|date=March 18, 2013|isbn=1481865617|page=142}} The brother Nahum was buried in a mass grave in the Jewish cemetery.{{cite book|title=Children of Dust and Heaven : A Diary from Nazi Occupation through the Holocaust|last=Heilbrunn|first=Stefania|date=March 18, 2013|isbn=1481865617|page=184}} == Chapters of the diary == The diary begins with the introductory chapter that describes the events between the summer of 1939 and the occupation of Radomsko by the Germans in September 1939. The second part of the diary consists of 27 dated entries starting at 21 April 1941 describing the events of the war and ghetto life along with the typical account of a teenage girl's emotions. == Death == The last entry in the diary in Miriam's handwriting was on 7 October 1942, when Miriam was 18. Between 9 and 12 October 1942 about 14,000 residents of the ghetto were sent to [[Treblinka]]. In the last page of the notebook appears an entry in a different, adult, handwriting, possibly by the Polish policeman who was the son of the woman who passed the notebook to Stefania Heilbrunn:
On the evening of the 24 October 1942 she surrendered, together with her mother, to a Polish policeman on duty on Limanewskeigo Str. They asked to be taken to the Judenrat, as they have been hiding for a week in a lavatory and had enough of it all. During the last 3 days they ate raw groats. They were taken to the Police station and the next day left with a transport by lorry to [[Częstochowa]].
In one of the diary's last entries, about a month before her death, Miriam wrote:
It may seem silly, but only a step away from death I still worry about my diary. I would not want for it to meet a miserable end in an oven or on a rubbish heap. I wish somebody could find it – even if it be only a German – and would read it. I wish that these scribblings, though they record barely a fraction of the cruelties, would one day serve as a true and faithful document of our times.{{cite book|title=Children of Dust and Heaven : A Diary from Nazi Occupation through the Holocaust|last=Heilbrunn|first=Stefania|date=March 18, 2013|isbn=1481865617|page=133}}
==References== {{reflist}} == Further reading == * ''Children of Dust and Heaven: A Collective memoir'', Cape Town: S. Heilbrunn, 1978. ** Stefania Heilbrunn; Miriam Chaszczewacki, ''Children of Dust and Heaven: A Diary from Nazi Occupation Through the Holocaust; A Collective Memoir'', new ed., Pacific Palisades, Calif.: Remember Point, 2012. ** "KINDER AUS STAUB UND HIMMEL: EIN TAGEBUCH AUS DER NS-BESATZUNGSZEIT WÄHREND DES HOLOCAUSTS: GERMAN EDITION" by Stefania Heilbrunn == External links == *[http://muzeum.radomsko.pl/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/pdf/likwidacja_getta_radomsko.pdf History of the Radomsko ghetto (Polish)], including portions of Miriam's diary on the [http://muzeum.radomsko.pl/ Radomsko history museum site] *[http://radomsko.naszemiasto.pl/artykul/miriam-film-zs-g-nr-5-w-radomsku-finale-konkursu-filmoteka,803600,art,t,id,tm.html Student film] [http://www.lo2.radomsko.pl/portal/pliki/kino9.pdf inspired by the diary] *[https://www.europeana.eu/portal/record/9200418/BibliographicResource_3000125966773.html?query=what%3A%22Dermatoglyphics%22 Miriam Chaszczewacki’s Diary], Europeana {{authority control}} [[Category:Children who died in the Holocaust]] [[Category:The Holocaust in Poland]] [[Category:World War II memoirs]] [[Category:Diaries]] [[Category:Personal accounts of the Holocaust]] [[Category:Books published posthumously]] [[Category:Polish diarists]] [[Category:Polish women writers]] [[Category:People who died in ghettos in Nazi-occupied Europe]] [[Category:Jewish women writers]]

{{italic title}} [[File:Memling Triptych of Family Moreel.jpg|thumb|560px|Hans Memling, ''Moreel Triptych'', 1484. [[oil painting|Oil]]-on-wood, 291cm x 121.1cm]] [[File:Hans Memling - Triptych of the Family Moreel (closed) - WGA14933.jpg|thumb|300px|Exterior panels; [[John the Baptist]] (left) and [[Saint George]] (right)]] The '''''Moreel Triptych''''' (or the '''''Saint Christopher Altarpiece''''') is the name given to a 1484 panel painting by the [[Early Netherlandish painting|Early Netherlandish]] painter [[Hans Memling]] (d. 1494). It was [[Donor portrait|commissioned]] by the prominent Bruges politician, merchant and banker Willem Moreel (d. 1501) and his wife Barbara van Vlaenderberch, née van Hertsvelde (d. 1499). It was intended as their [[epitaph]] at the chapel<ref name="b100">Blum, 100</ref> of the [[St. James's Church, Bruges]], an extension they paid for, to the funerary church of Willem's family, where the couple intended to be interred in an underground tomb before the altar.
The inner center panel of the [[triptych]] altarpiece show [[Saint Christopher]] holding the [[Christ Child]], with [[Saint Maurus]] to his left and Saint Gills to his right. Willem Moreel kneels in prayer and venerating the saints in the left-hand panel with their five sons. Barbara kneels with eleven of their daughters on the right panel. The exterior panels are probably an early 16th-century addition, completed after the donor's and artist's deaths.
The triptych was installed on the altar of St. James's Church in 1484.<ref name="ap">Pearson, Andrea. ''Envisioning Gender in Burgundian Devotional Art, 1350–1530''. Ashgate, 2005. {{ISBN|978-07-5465-154-3}}</ref> It is in its original frames, which are each inscribed with the words ''anno Domini 1484'', or a variant containing the year, on their lower borders.<ref name="r352" /> The altarpiece has a strong association with the [[Benedictine]] order; three of the figures are Benedictine monks or saints.<ref name="b101">Blum, 101</ref> It is to dedicated to [[Saint Maurus]] and St Giles, the latter a Benedictine hermit. Today the work is located in the [[Groeningemuseum]] in Bruges.
==Commission== [[File: Hans Memling - Portraits of Willem Moreel and His Wife - WGA14854.jpg|thumb|300px|left|Hans Memling, ''Portrait of the family Moreel'', 1482. Royal Museums of Fine Arts of Belgium]] The family of Willem Moreel are known to have lived in Bruges since the 13th century.<ref name="b97">Blum, 97</ref> Willem inherited land and a title lord of Oostcleyhem from his father. During his career he was twice appointed both [[alderman]] and [[burgomaster]] of the city, as well as its [[bailiff]] and later its [[treasurer]]. He was named as one of the fortieth riches men in the city in a 1490 tax list. The couple has eighteen children. Memling earlier portrayed the couple in 1482, with a pair of panel portraits now in the [[Royal Museums of Fine Arts of Belgium]].
Saint James's Church was his family's burial ground and was founded in the 12th century.<ref name="b100" /> It underwent a major reconstruction in the late 15th century, which Willem Moreel partly financed along with members of the prominent [[Portinari Altarpiece|Portinari]], Gros and Moor families.<ref name="b98" /> The couple intended to be buried with the church building, in a chapel they had paid for and dedicated to saints Gills and Maurus, with space left before the altar as burial space for two people. To the same end, they commissioned the triptych from Memling, then a highly prominent, prestigious and sought-after painter, to be placed on the chapel altar, and only interred in the chapel in 1504, at the request of their son John.<ref name="b98" /> Barbara died in 1899, he followed in 1501.<ref name="b98">Blum, 98</ref>
The Moreels did not at first get their wishes as to their burial places. Their standing and political security hamper by the struggles after the deaths of [[Charles the Bold]] in 1477 and [[Mary of Burgundy]] in 1482 and the struggle with [[Maximilian I, Holy Roman Emperor|Maximilian of Austria]]. Willem was a prominent adversary of Maximilian, and was imprisoned in October 1481 for six months.<ref name="r356">Ridderbos et al, 356</ref> On their deaths, were each buried on exterior church grounds.<ref name="b98" /> They were not moved to their intended resting places in front of the chapel altar until 1504.
==Interior== The inner panels share a continuous overcast skyline and broad landscape,<ref name="r352">Ridderbos et all, 352</ref> which contains two city-scapes, cottages and a meadow with a variety of trees animals and wild strawberries, daisies, daffodils and other recognisable flowers and plants.<ref name="m141">Michiels, 141</ref> Adding to the sense of harmony, both wing panels are identically composed, excepting the number of children.<ref name="j163">Jacobs, 163</ref> Sixteen of the couple's eighteen children are shown in total. However, some of the figures are later additions, painted over the first layers of oil and pigment.<ref name="ap" />
The figures were identified in the mid 19th century by James H. Weale through their facial characteristics and extant established portraits, through the commonality of Christian names from family names to some of the saints, city records, and the examination of headstones in the Saint James graveyard.<ref name="r356" />
The inner panels are in relatively good condition for late 15th-century oil paintings, but have suffered some damage and paint loss, and have been depreciated by ill-advised restorations and touch-up work.<ref name="m141">Michiels, 141</ref>
===Center panel=== [[File:Hans Memling - Triptych of the Family Moreel (central panel) - WGA14930.jpg|320px|thumb|Center panel with Saint Christopher, and Saint Maurus to his left and Saint Gills to the right<ref name="j163" />]] The central figure is [[Saint Christopher]], patron saint of travelers, who shares his feast day, July 25, with Saint James, after whom the containing church is named.<ref name="b100" /> He is shown standing in water as he crosses a river or inlet, carrying the [[Child Jesus]] on his shoulders. He is presented with his attributes, including a large staff, a symbol of Christ's miraculous presence,<ref name="b101" /> and is intended as a protector against sudden death.<ref name="vp">"[http://vlaamseprimitieven.vlaamsekunstcollectie.be/en/collection/moreel-triptych Moreel Triptych]". [[Flemish Art Collection]]. Retrieved 16 November 2017</ref> Christopher is dressed in a blue coat, covered with a long red cape folded over his right shoulder. He closely resembles depictions in both [[Jan van Eyck]]'s ''[[Ghent Altarpiece]]'' and now lost ''[[Saint Christopher (after van Eyck)|Saint Christopher]]'', by whom Memling was deeply influenced by.<ref>"[http://www.kmska.be/en/collectie/Restauratie/Hans_Memling/Over_het_kunstwerk.html The Paintings]". [[Royal Museums of Fine Arts of Belgium]]. Retrieved 16 November 2017</ref>
On the left is Saint Maurus who holds a [[crosier]] and looks at an open book. Saint Gills stands to the right, standing with his attributes, an arrow and a [[deer|doe]].<ref name="r352" /> Both are dressed in long black robes and are holding books.
===Left panel=== [[File:Hans Memling 069.jpg|left|thumb|180px|Left panel, with Willem Moreel, sons, and Saint Wilhemus van Maleval]] The left interior wing shows Willem Moreel kneeling, his hands clasped in prayer, before an open prayer book. His hair is short in a [[bowl cut]],<ref name="m141" /> wears a fur-lined dress and black [[Doublet (clothing)|doublet]], a very fashionable outfit in the 1480s. Behind him are his five male children, also shown kneeling. Of the sons, two are known to have died in infancy. Willem was the oldest, while John and George are thought to have commissioned the outer panels after their parents' death (see below).
The Moreels are presented by Saint Wilhemus van Maleval,<ref name="vp" /> who stands among them, dressed a fur-lined black coat over army clothing.<ref name="m141" /> He places his hand on Willem's shoulder, as he guides and presents him to Christopher in the center panel.<ref name="ap" />
===Right panel=== [[File:Hans Memling 071.jpg|thumb|180px|Right panel with Barbara Moreel, daughters, and Saint Barbara]] The right interior wing presents Barbara Moreel with her eleven of her thirteen daughters,<ref name="j163" /> who all also kneel in prayer before an open book. Barbara wears a truncated [[hennin]], a [[damask]] silk dress with a white collar, and a wide red belt with a golden buckle. They are presented by [[Saint Barbara]], patron of the donor's wife,<ref name="r355">Ridderbos et all, 355</ref> who is shown standing before the tower where she was, by legend, imprisoned, which through innovative use of [[Perspective (graphical)|perspective]], she seems to hold in her hand.<ref name="m141" />
<!--[[File:Hans Memling 049.jpg|thumb|left|180px|Hans Membling, ''[[Sibylla Sambetha]]'', 1480]]--> One of the daughters, Catherine, earlier posed for Memling's 1480 ''[[Sibylla Sambetha]]''.<ref name="m141" /> The eldest daughter, shown directly behind Barbra, and also in a black dress, is known to have become a Dominican nun. The girl in the light brown clothing, black v-neck and transparent [[veil]] has been identified as Maria from her name written in her headband, their second born daughter, given her linear position in the painting. Genealogical research notes that the couple has two daughters named Marie; but is assumed one died in infancy and the second was named after her. Efforts to name other of the daughters have been unsuccessful.<ref name="r360">Ridderbos et al, 360</ref>
Not all of the daughters were painted by Memling; examination by the art historian Dirk De Vos identifies at least six that are later additions, layered over the original landscape. Some of these additions can be explained by daughters born after the 1484 completion date, and were probably added by members of Memling's workshop. The left-hand panel containing sons underwent similar updated.<ref name="r360" />
==Exterior== The outer part of the wings contains [[grisaille]] representations of [[John the Baptist]] with his lamb and staff (left wing) and [[Saint George]] in full [[armour]], slaying the dragon (right wing) with a lance. The panels may have been completed after the deaths of Willem and Barbara, and dated as c 1504 by a number of art historians, probably commissioned by two of their sons,<ref>Shirley Blum considers this "highly likely". See Blum, 102</ref> Jan (John) and Jaris (George), as the final, successful, effort to have their parents interred within the chapel space.<ref name="b102">Blum, 102</ref>

"Early Netherlandish Triptychs: A Study in Patronage". ''Speculum'', Volume 47, No. 2, April 1972 * Jacobs, Lynn. ''Opening Doors: The Early Netherlandish Triptych Reinterpreted''.
